trans-unit.source: Node.js Getting Started Guide | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Node.js Getting Started Guide | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a simple Node.js web application and deploy it to an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a simple Node.js web application and deploy it to an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service
trans-unit.target: Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Node.js
trans-unit.target: Node.js

trans-unit.source: .NET
trans-unit.target: .NET

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to create a simple Node.js application running
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to create a simple Node.js application running

trans-unit.source: in an Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: in an Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: Cloud Services are the building blocks of
trans-unit.target: Cloud Services are the building blocks of

trans-unit.source: scalable cloud applications in Azure.
trans-unit.target: scalable cloud applications in Azure.

trans-unit.source: They allow the separation and independent
trans-unit.target: They allow the separation and independent

trans-unit.source: management and scale-out of front-end and back-end components of your application.
trans-unit.target: management and scale-out of front-end and back-end components of your application.

trans-unit.source: Cloud Services
trans-unit.target: Cloud Services

trans-unit.source: provide a robust dedicated virtual machine for hosting each role reliably.
trans-unit.target: provide a robust dedicated virtual machine for hosting each role reliably.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Cloud Services, and how they compare to Azure Websites and Virtual machines, see [Azure Websites, Cloud Services and Virtual Machines comparison](../choose-web-site-cloud-service-vm.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Cloud Services, and how they compare to Azure Websites and Virtual machines, see [Azure Websites, Cloud Services and Virtual Machines comparison](../choose-web-site-cloud-service-vm.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Looking to build a simple website?
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Looking to build a simple website?

trans-unit.source: If your scenario involves just a simple website front-end, consider using a lightweight web app. You can easily upgrade to a Cloud Service as your web app grows and your requirements change.
trans-unit.target: If your scenario involves just a simple website front-end, consider using a lightweight web app. You can easily upgrade to a Cloud Service as your web app grows and your requirements change.

trans-unit.source: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web application hosted inside a web role.
trans-unit.target: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web application hosted inside a web role.

trans-unit.source: You
trans-unit.target: You

trans-unit.source: will use the compute emulator to test your application locally, then deploy it
trans-unit.target: will use the compute emulator to test your application locally, then deploy it

trans-unit.source: using PowerShell command-line tools.
trans-unit.target: using PowerShell command-line tools.

trans-unit.source: The application is a simple "hello world" application:
trans-unit.target: The application is a simple "hello world" application:

trans-unit.source: A web browser displaying the Hello World web page
trans-unit.target: A web browser displaying the Hello World web page

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial uses Azure PowerShell, which requires Windows.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial uses Azure PowerShell, which requires Windows.

trans-unit.source: Install and configure [Azure Powershell](../install-configure-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: Install and configure [Azure Powershell](../install-configure-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Download and install the [Azure SDK for .NET 2.7](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48178).
trans-unit.target: Download and install the [Azure SDK for .NET 2.7](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48178).

trans-unit.source: In the install setup, select:
trans-unit.target: In the install setup, select:

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftAzureAuthoringTools

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftAzureComputeEmulator
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftAzureComputeEmulator

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Cloud Service project
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Cloud Service project

trans-unit.source: Perform the following tasks to create a new Azure Cloud Service project, along with basic Node.js scaffolding:
trans-unit.target: Perform the following tasks to create a new Azure Cloud Service project, along with basic Node.js scaffolding:

trans-unit.source: Run **Azure PowerShell** as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Run **Azure PowerShell** as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: (From the **Start Menu** or **Start Screen**, search for **Azure PowerShell**.)
trans-unit.target: (From the **Start Menu** or **Start Screen**, search for **Azure PowerShell**.)

trans-unit.source: [Connect PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md#how-to-connect-to-your-subscription) to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: [Connect PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md#how-to-connect-to-your-subscription) to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following PowerShell cmdlet to create to create the project:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following PowerShell cmdlet to create to create the project:

trans-unit.source: The result of the New-AzureService helloworld command
trans-unit.target: The result of the New-AzureService helloworld command

trans-unit.source: The **New-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet generates a basic structure for publishing a Node.js application to a Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: The **New-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet generates a basic structure for publishing a Node.js application to a Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: It contains configuration files necessary for publishing to Azure.
trans-unit.target: It contains configuration files necessary for publishing to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet also changes your working directory to the directory for the service.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet also changes your working directory to the directory for the service.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet creates the following files:
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet creates the following files:

trans-unit.source: **ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg**,
trans-unit.target: **ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg**,

trans-unit.source: **ServiceConfiguration.Local.cscfg** and **ServiceDefinition.csdef**:
trans-unit.target: **ServiceConfiguration.Local.cscfg** and **ServiceDefinition.csdef**:

trans-unit.source: Azure-specific files necessary for publishing your
trans-unit.target: Azure-specific files necessary for publishing your

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see
trans-unit.target: For more information, see

trans-unit.source: [Overview of Creating a Hosted Service for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: [Overview of Creating a Hosted Service for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: **deploymentSettings.json**: Stores local settings that are used by
trans-unit.target: **deploymentSettings.json**: Stores local settings that are used by

trans-unit.source: the Azure PowerShell deployment cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: the Azure PowerShell deployment cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to add a new web role:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to add a new web role:

trans-unit.source: The output of the Add-AzureNodeWebRole command.
trans-unit.target: The output of the Add-AzureNodeWebRole command.

trans-unit.source: The **Add-AzureNodeWebRole** cmdlet creates a basic Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: The **Add-AzureNodeWebRole** cmdlet creates a basic Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: It also modifies the **.csfg** and **.csdef** files to add configuration entries for the new role.
trans-unit.target: It also modifies the **.csfg** and **.csdef** files to add configuration entries for the new role.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not specify a role name, a default name is used.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you do not specify a role name, a default name is used.

trans-unit.source: You can provide a name as the first cmdlet parameter: `Add-AzureNodeWebRole MyRole`
trans-unit.target: You can provide a name as the first cmdlet parameter: `Add-AzureNodeWebRole MyRole`

trans-unit.source: The Node.js app is defined in the file **server.js**, located in the directory for the web role (**WebRole1** by default).
trans-unit.target: The Node.js app is defined in the file **server.js**, located in the directory for the web role (**WebRole1** by default).

trans-unit.source: Here is the code:
trans-unit.target: Here is the code:

trans-unit.source: This code is essentially the same as the "Hello World" sample on the [nodejs.org][] website, except it uses the port number assigned by the cloud environment.
trans-unit.target: This code is essentially the same as the "Hello World" sample on the [nodejs.org][] website, except it uses the port number assigned by the cloud environment.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the application to Azure

trans-unit.source: Download the Azure publishing settings
trans-unit.target: Download the Azure publishing settings

trans-unit.source: To deploy your application to Azure, you must first download the publishing settings for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To deploy your application to Azure, you must first download the publishing settings for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Run the following Azure PowerShell cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Run the following Azure PowerShell cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: This will use your browser to navigate to the publish settings download page.
trans-unit.target: This will use your browser to navigate to the publish settings download page.

trans-unit.source: You may be prompted to log in with a Microsoft Account.
trans-unit.target: You may be prompted to log in with a Microsoft Account.

trans-unit.source: If so, use the account associated with your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If so, use the account associated with your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Save the downloaded profile to a file location you can easily access.
trans-unit.target: Save the downloaded profile to a file location you can easily access.

trans-unit.source: Run following cmdlet to import the publishing profile you downloaded:
trans-unit.target: Run following cmdlet to import the publishing profile you downloaded:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] After importing the publish settings, consider deleting the downloaded .publishSettings file, because it contains information that could allow someone to access your account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] After importing the publish settings, consider deleting the downloaded .publishSettings file, because it contains information that could allow someone to access your account.

trans-unit.source: Publish the application
trans-unit.target: Publish the application

trans-unit.source: To publish, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: To publish, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: **-ServiceName** specifies the name for the deployment.
trans-unit.target: **-ServiceName** specifies the name for the deployment.

trans-unit.source: This must be a unique name, otherwise the publish process will fail.
trans-unit.target: This must be a unique name, otherwise the publish process will fail.

trans-unit.source: The **Get-Date** command tacks on a date/time string that should make the name unique.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-Date** command tacks on a date/time string that should make the name unique.

trans-unit.source: **-Location** specifies the datacenter that the application will be hosted in.
trans-unit.target: **-Location** specifies the datacenter that the application will be hosted in.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available datacenters, use the **Get-AzureLocation** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available datacenters, use the **Get-AzureLocation** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: **-Launch** opens a browser window and navigates to the hosted service after deployment has completed.
trans-unit.target: **-Launch** opens a browser window and navigates to the hosted service after deployment has completed.

trans-unit.source: After publishing succeeds, you will see a response similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: After publishing succeeds, you will see a response similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The output of the Publish-AzureService command
trans-unit.target: The output of the Publish-AzureService command

trans-unit.source: It can take several minutes for the application to deploy and become available when first published.
trans-unit.target: It can take several minutes for the application to deploy and become available when first published.

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment has completed, a browser window will open and navigate to the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment has completed, a browser window will open and navigate to the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: A browser window displaying the hello world page.
trans-unit.target: A browser window displaying the hello world page.

trans-unit.source: The URL indicates the page is hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: The URL indicates the page is hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Your application is now running on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Your application is now running on Azure.

trans-unit.source: The **Publish-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet performs the following steps:
trans-unit.target: The **Publish-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet performs the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Creates a package to deploy.
trans-unit.target: Creates a package to deploy.

trans-unit.source: The package contains all the files in your application folder.
trans-unit.target: The package contains all the files in your application folder.

trans-unit.source: Creates a new **storage account** if one does not exist.
trans-unit.target: Creates a new **storage account** if one does not exist.

trans-unit.source: The Azure storage account is used to store the application package during deployment.
trans-unit.target: The Azure storage account is used to store the application package during deployment.

trans-unit.source: You can safely delete the storage account after deployment is done.
trans-unit.target: You can safely delete the storage account after deployment is done.

trans-unit.source: Creates a new **cloud service** if one does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: Creates a new **cloud service** if one does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: A **cloud service** is the container in which your application is hosted when it is deployed to Azure.
trans-unit.target: A **cloud service** is the container in which your application is hosted when it is deployed to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Overview of Creating a Hosted Service for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Overview of Creating a Hosted Service for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: Publishes the deployment package to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Publishes the deployment package to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Stopping and deleting your application
trans-unit.target: Stopping and deleting your application

trans-unit.source: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you can avoid extra costs.
trans-unit.target: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you can avoid extra costs.

trans-unit.source: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time consumed.
trans-unit.target: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time consumed.

trans-unit.source: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed, even if the instances are not running and are in the stopped state.
trans-unit.target: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed, even if the instances are not running and are in the stopped state.

trans-unit.source: In the Windows PowerShell window, stop the service deployment created in the previous section with the following cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: In the Windows PowerShell window, stop the service deployment created in the previous section with the following cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Stopping the service may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: Stopping the service may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: When the service is stopped, you receive a message indicating that it has stopped.
trans-unit.target: When the service is stopped, you receive a message indicating that it has stopped.

trans-unit.source: The status of the Stop-AzureService command
trans-unit.target: The status of the Stop-AzureService command

trans-unit.source: To delete the service, call the following cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To delete the service, call the following cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter **Y** to delete the service.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter **Y** to delete the service.

trans-unit.source: Deleting the service may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: Deleting the service may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: After the service has been deleted you receive a message indicating that the service was deleted.
trans-unit.target: After the service has been deleted you receive a message indicating that the service was deleted.

trans-unit.source: The status of the Remove-AzureService command
trans-unit.target: The status of the Remove-AzureService command

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Deleting the service does not delete the storage account that was created when the service was initially published, and you will continue to be billed for storage used.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Deleting the service does not delete the storage account that was created when the service was initially published, and you will continue to be billed for storage used.

trans-unit.source: For more information on deleting a storage account, see [How to Delete a Storage Account from an Azure Subscription](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/hh531562.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information on deleting a storage account, see [How to Delete a Storage Account from an Azure Subscription](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/hh531562.aspx).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
